And all by the persuasive tones that sell— So runs the legend—from his voice and shell. 'Twas wisdom’s office then to mark the line Betwixt what is profane and what divine ; The rights of state and subject to adjust; Put down concubinage and roving lust; Define what man and wife might do and should: Build cities up. and grave their laws on wood. Thus came high honour and abounding praise To heaven-commissioned poets and their lays. Then peerless Homer and Tyrtaeus' song Made manly hearts for martial conflicts strong. In rhythmic strains men learned the will of sate, Verse taught the duties of our mortal state; Sweet poets sang. and, sostened by their art, Kings dropped their state, and felt they had a heart.

Plays were invented, and brought mirth and cheer To close the long hard labours of the year.† No need to blush, then, sor the god that sings Responsive to the Muse's sounding strings !

The charms of verse—the question is not new— Are they to art or inborn genius due?
